title: SB 707
content: The State of California enacts the following. Section 626.9 of the Penal Code, known as the Gun-Free School Zone Act of 1995, prohibits possessing a firearm in a school zone without written permission from school authorities. Exceptions include possession in a residence, business, or private property not part of school grounds. When transporting an unloaded pistol, revolver, or concealed firearm in a locked container or trunk of a vehicle, it is allowed under state law. This does not apply to other firearms not capable of being concealed on the person. When in grave danger due to a restraining order against a threatening individual or exempt from carrying a concealed firearm prohibition, one may carry a concealed firearm. When holding a valid license, a person can carry a firearm within 1,000 feet of a school but not on school grounds. It is unlawful to discharge a firearm in a school zone with reckless disregard for safety, except under certain conditions. "Concealed firearm" is defined as in Sections 25400 and 25610. In a school zone, possessing a firearm can lead to imprisonment for two, three, or five years. Possessing a firearm within 1,000 feet of a school can result in imprisonment for two, three, or five years under certain circumstances, such as prior felony convictions or being prohibited from possessing a firearm. Possessing a concealed firearm near a school can lead to imprisonment for one to seven years, depending on the circumstances. Every person convicted under this section for a misdemeanor violation of possessing a concealed firearm near a school and with a previous misdemeanor offense shall be imprisoned in a county jail for not less than three months. For felony violations with a previous misdemeanor offense, imprisonment for not less than three months is also required. For felony violations of possessing a concealed firearm near a school with a previous felony offense, imprisonment in a county jail for not less than three months is required. The court must impose a three-month minimum sentence for felony violations of possessing a concealed firearm near a school with a previous felony offense, unless probation or a suspended sentence is deemed more appropriate for the interests of justice. Possessing a loaded firearm on university campus grounds without permission from the college president or designated authority is punishable by imprisonment for two to four years. The university must post notices at entrances on noncontiguous property stating that firearms are prohibited. Possessing a firearm on university campus grounds without written permission from the college president or designated authority is punishable by imprisonment for one, two, or three years. The university must post notices at entrances on noncontiguous property stating that firearms are prohibited. A firearm is considered loaded when there is an unexpended cartridge or shell attached to it. This section does not require posting notice about the prohibited conduct. This section exempts certain individuals from the regulations, including peace officers, military personnel, and armored vehicle guards. Certain individuals are exempt from the regulations outlined in Section 30310 of the Penal Code, including security guards authorized to carry loaded firearms, existing shooting ranges at schools, honorably retired peace officers, and peace officers appointed under Section 830.6. Section 30310 of the Penal Code prohibits carrying ammunition on school grounds without written permission from school authorities, except for sworn law enforcement officers. Exemptions include peace officers, military personnel on duty, and individuals assisting law enforcement officers. (5) An armored vehicle guard, peace officers, honorably retired peace officers, and individuals carrying ammunition in a locked container or trunk in a motor vehicle are exempt from the prohibition on carrying ammunition on school grounds as stated in Section 30310 of the Penal Code. A violation of this section can result in up to six months in jail, a fine of up to $1,000, or both. No reimbursement is required for local agencies or school districts due to the creation of a new crime or infraction, elimination of a crime or infraction, or changes in penalties.
